burlap.datastructures

Class HashIndexedHeap<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • burlap.datastructures.HashIndexedHeap<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - any Java object
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Iterable<T>

    public class HashIndexedHeap<T>
extends Object
implements Iterable<T>
    An implementation of a hash map backed heap/priority queue. This data structure allows efficient O(1) "contains" checks and efficient O(lg(n)) modifications of entries already in the heap that with a typical Java PriorityQueue would require linear updates. This data structure is especially useful for planning algorithms like A* that keep a priority queue of states, but may need to update their priority if a better path to them is found.

    By default, the heap is a max heap (which results in elements with the highest priority being dequeued first), but it may also be set to be a min heap.

    Author:
    James MacGlashan

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      protected Map<T,Integer> arrayIndexMap
      Hash map from objects to their index in the heap
      protected boolean maxHeap
      If true, this is ordered according to a max heap; if false ordered according to a min heap.
      protected List<T> nodesArray
      Heap ordered list of objects
      protected Comparator<T> priorityCompare
      A comparator to compare objects
      protected int size
      Number of objects in the heap

      • iterator

      • satisifiesHeap

        public boolean satisifiesHeap()
        This method returns whether the data structure stored is in fact a heap (costs linear time). This method should only be used for debug purposes such as when a heap's elements have their priority changed from multiple sources and it needs to be made sure that each element is being properly refreshed within the heap. Note that to be a heap, each node must be greater than or equal to its children.
        Returns:
        true if the stored data is a valid heap; false otherwise.
